p: Increases in global temperatures since the late 1800s [ 14] have led to shifts in the ranges of many animals [ 15]. Insects in particular are sensitive to changes in temperature, with consequences for the transmission of vector-borne pathogens [ 7, 16, 17]. Mechanistic models, capable of explaining how recent climate change [ 14] has affected vector distribution and abundance, could be used to predict future disease risks [ 16], but existing studies often rely instead on statistical correlations [ 8, 18â€“ 20].
